unnormalised: Organic Farming: Going Back to Our Roots, Jai Kisan!
normalised: Organic Farming: Going Back to Our Roots, Jai Kisan!

unnormalised: Hey there, fellow farmers and food lovers! Ever wondered what's buzzing in the world of agriculture besides the usual pesticides and fertilizers? It's organic farming, folks! Think of it as our grandmothers' way of farming, updated with a bit of modern knowledge. It's all about growing food the natural way, respecting Mother Earth, and keeping our plates (and bodies!) happy.
normalised: Hey there, fellow farmers and food lovers! Ever wondered what's buzzing in the world of agriculture besides the usual pesticides and fertilizers? It's organic farming, folks! Think of it as our grandmothers' way of farming, updated with a bit of modern knowledge. It's all about growing food the natural way, respecting Mother Earth, and keeping our plates (and bodies!) happy.

unnormalised: Now, organic farming ain’t just a trend; it's a philosophy. Instead of dousing fields with chemicals, we’re talking about using stuff like cow dung (gomutra too, sometimes!), compost, and crop rotation to enrich the soil. Remember that dusty old agriculture textbook from school? Well, it’s probably more relevant now than ever! We're basically mimicking nature's own processes. Think of it like this: instead of forcing the plants to grow with artificial boosters, we're giving them a nutritious "desi" diet.

unnormalised: Why should we bother, you ask? Well, for starters, organic produce is often packed with more nutrients and tastes better, says Dr. Patil from the Mahatma Phule Krishi Vidyapeeth in Rahuri. Plus, it's kinder to the environment. No more chemical runoff polluting our rivers or harming the beneficial insects. Remember those fireflies we used to see as kids? Organic farming helps bring them back!

unnormalised: In villages like Piplantri in Rajasthan, organic farming is more than just agriculture; it's a way of life. They even plant 111 trees every time a girl child is born – how cool is that? It’s about building a sustainable future for generations to come.
normalised: In villages like Piplantri in Rajasthan, organic farming is more than just agriculture; it's a way of life. They even plant one hundred and eleven trees every time a girl child is born – how cool is that? It’s about building a sustainable future for generations to come.

unnormalised: Of course, transitioning to organic farming isn’t a walk in the park. It requires patience, careful planning, and a bit of trial and error. Initially, yields might be a bit lower, and you might have to deal with more weeds and pests. But the long-term benefits – healthier soil, healthier food, and a healthier planet – are totally worth it. The initial investment might seem high, say around Rs. 50,000 for a 1-acre plot, but think of the savings on chemical fertilizers and pesticides!

unnormalised: The government, through schemes like Paramparagat Krishi Vikas Yojana (PKVY), is also providing support to farmers who want to go organic. They offer subsidies and training programs to help farmers adopt organic practices. Even small farmers with just a few sq ft of land can benefit.

unnormalised: So, next time you're at the market, look for the "Jaivik Bharat" logo. It's a sign that the produce is certified organic and grown with love and respect for nature. Let's support our organic farmers and create a healthier, more sustainable food system. Jai Hind!
